comment_text: Olympic National Park is temporarily closed as Washington, the US, and the world work to mitigate the spread of the COVID-19 virus. We filmed this series in early January and are currently at home practicing social distancing. We hope you and your community of friends and family are staying healthy as we work to #flattenthecurve.

If people want a longer, but only 50 minutes, explanation of all this by one of the scientist doing the actual research. Search for Dr. Victor Camp “The Yellowstone Hotspot Track and the Origins of the Columbia River Basalt”.Its on YT under the EWU Geoscience channel.

Ah, the next episode in the ad trilogy.  Welp, time to do what I sometimes do with real life ads on television--leave it playing in the background and go get a snack!  As in, without pausing.
To learn more PNW geology, check out Nick Zentner on YouTube.

You REALLY should pay a visit to -- and build a series of field episodes around -- Geology prof. Nick Zentner at Central Wash. University in Ellensburg. He's media savvy and already has an online audience, and he's very (very) good at explaining the physical model behind the Yellowstone Hotspot, connecting the "Siletzia" story all the way through to it's present manifestation under NW Wyoming, along with many of the other unusual stories of Pacific NW geology. HINT : there's a LONG chain of geophysical evidence between the two, including the massive basalt flows that formed the Columbia basin, et al. Lastly, if the Siletzia model blows your mind, you'll love the parallel and evolving "Baja-BC" narrative.

Saying that Washington is no where near Yellowstone is incorrect. The Southeast corner of WA is a narrow state (idaho) away from the NW corner of Wyoming. Eastern Washington is a wonderful geology lab with the ancient lava flows and erosion caused by the Missoula flood when the ice age ended. Idaho has Craters of the Moon National Monument/Preserve leading right to Yellowstone.

The story of Yellowstone is a complicated one and difficult to find but yes there are multiple examples of it throughout the northern western states. A better and more visible example of a hotspot is Hawaii. If you google earth look at Hawaii you will see a trail of islands going north all the way to Russia. Those are old Hawaii's that have eroded and moved on off the hotspot.

It's called brand trust.   Here on YouTube, we viewers feel like we share a connection to content creators that make content we like... it's like we form an 'in-group' family of entertainment.   We usually trust that we will learn some cool stuff and be entertained, with a little bit of add space to earn revenue.  Content creators break that trust when they try to pass off a full blown commercial with some content as a regular video.  It turns that trust into something sleezy.  I can't speak for others, but I would have lost a lot less trust in this channel if someone had been upfront by saying something as simple as "Hey guys, this video is going to be HEAVILY saturated with a car commercial, but it really helps us out with our money flow so we can make a lot of cool new videos in the future.  Please bear with us and good things will come."  (ya know, showing trust in your audience)  .... I'll wager that'd have helped mitigate the largest total of 'unlikes' of any of your videos this series has already received.   As it stands right now, I think the sleezy approach degrades your brand.
